results.title: Voters Have Expanded Medicaid in 6 States. Is South Dakota Next?
results.abstract: Ten years after the Supreme Court ruled that states did not have to expand Medicaid, the politics are changing in states like South Dakota, where rural hospitals and nursing homes are struggling.
des_facet: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

multimedia.caption: An unlikely coalition of farmers, business leaders, hospital executives and clergy members have coalesced around a ballot measure that would enshrine Medicaid expansion in the South Dakota Constitution.
multimedia.copyright: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

results.title: Stoked by Republicans, Fears of Crime Loom Large for Midterm Voters
results.abstract: Republican candidates are focusing on crime and public safety, but their message is rooted not so much in data or policy as in voters’ feelings of unease.
results.byline: By Julie Bosman, Jack Healy and Campbell Robertson

multimedia.caption: Across the country, Republican candidates have sought to blame Democrats for crime problems. Billboards in Philadelphia attacked the Democratic candidate for U.S. Senate, John Fetterman.

results.title: Fueled by Billionaires, Political Spending Shatters Records Again
results.abstract: In the money race between America’s billionaires and small donors, the emerging political oligarchy is showing staying power. Both parties have megadonors, but Republicans have far more.

multimedia.caption: Samuel Bankman-Fried is the Democrat who made arguably the biggest splash for his party. His $37 million in giving helped fund the Democrats’ two main super PACs.

results.title: A Warming Siberia, Wracked by Wildfires, Nears a Crucial Threshold
results.abstract: Nearly 23 million acres burned from 1982 to 2020. But almost half of that occurred in 2019 and 2020, and the region may be near a threshold beyond which extreme fires become more common.
